questions.question: What is the defining characteristic of supervised learning?

options.A: Learning from unlabeled data.
options.B: Learning through interaction with an environment.
options.C: Learning a mapping from input features to output targets based on labeled examples.
options.D: Discovering hidden patterns in data without any guidance.

questions.question: What are the two main types of supervised learning problems?

options.A: Clustering and dimensionality reduction.
options.B: Classification and regression.
options.C: Association rule mining and anomaly detection.

questions.question: In a classification problem, what type of output is the model trying to predict?

options.A: A continuous numerical value.
options.B: A discrete category or class label.
options.C: A probability distribution over possible outcomes.

questions.question: Which of the following algorithms is commonly used for classification?

options.A: Linear Regression
options.B: K-Means Clustering
options.C: Support Vector Machines (SVM)

questions.question: In a regression problem, what type of output is the model trying to predict?

options.A: A discrete category.
options.B: A continuous numerical value.
options.C: A binary outcome (0 or 1).

questions.question: Which of the following algorithms is commonly used for regression?

options.A: Logistic Regression
options.B: Decision Trees
options.C: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

questions.question: What is the role of a 'decision boundary' in a classification model?

options.A: To measure the error of the model.
options.B: To separate data points belonging to different classes in the feature space.
options.C: To visualize the distribution of the data.
options.D: To reduce the dimensionality of the data.

questions.question: What is the 'hypothesis space' in supervised learning?

options.A: The set of all possible input features.
options.B: The set of all possible output targets.
options.C: The set of all possible functions or models that the learning algorithm can learn.
options.D: The space where the data points are plotted.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'loss function' in supervised learning?

options.A: To evaluate the model's performance on the test set.
options.B: To quantify the difference between the model's predictions and the true target values during training.
options.C: To select the best features for the model.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common loss function used in linear regression?

options.A: Cross-Entropy Loss
options.B: Mean Squared Error (MSE)
options.C: Hinge Loss

questions.question: Which of the following is a common loss function used in binary classification?

options.A: Mean Absolute Error (MAE)
options.B: Mean Squared Error (MSE)
options.C: Binary Cross-Entropy Loss (Log Loss)

questions.question: What is the role of an 'optimizer' in training a supervised learning model?

options.A: To select the best model architecture.
options.B: To adjust the model's parameters (weights and biases) to minimize the loss function.
options.C: To preprocess the input data.

questions.question: What is 'regularization' and why is it used in supervised learning?

options.A: A technique for scaling input features.
options.B: A technique to prevent overfitting by adding a penalty term to the loss function, discouraging overly complex models.
options.C: A method for handling missing values in the data.
options.D: A way to visualize the model's decision boundaries.

questions.question: What are L1 and L2 regularization?

options.A: Two different types of activation functions.
options.B: Techniques for feature selection based on correlation.
options.C: Methods for adding a penalty term to the loss function based on the absolute magnitude (L1) or the squared magnitude (L2) of the model's weights.

questions.question: What is 'cross-validation' and why is it important in supervised learning?

options.A: A technique for training the model on multiple datasets.
options.B: A method for evaluating the model's generalization performance by splitting the data into multiple folds and training/testing on different combinations.
options.C: A way to reduce the dimensionality of the data.
options.D: A technique for visualizing the model's predictions.

questions.question: What are some common evaluation metrics for classification models?

options.A: Mean Squared Error, R-squared.
options.B: Precision, Recall, F1-score, Accuracy, AUC.
options.C: Silhouette score, Davies-Bouldin index.

questions.question: What are some common evaluation metrics for regression models?

options.A: Precision, Recall, F1-score.
options.B: Mean Squared Error (MSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), R-squared.
options.C: Entropy, Gini index.

questions.question: What is the difference between a linear and a non-linear supervised learning model?

options.A: Linear models can only handle numerical data, while non-linear models can handle categorical data.
options.B: Linear models learn a linear relationship between input features and the output, while non-linear models can learn more complex relationships.
options.C: Non-linear models are always more accurate than linear models.
options.D: Linear models are used for classification, while non-linear models are for regression.

questions.question: What is the role of feature importance in some supervised learning models (e.g., decision trees, random forests)?

options.A: To scale the features to a common range.
options.B: To identify which input features have the most significant impact on the model's predictions.
options.C: To encode categorical features into numerical form.
options.D: To reduce the dimensionality of the feature space.

questions.question: What is the goal of 'hyperparameter tuning' in supervised learning?

options.A: To train the model on more data.
options.B: To find the optimal values for the model's hyperparameters that lead to the best performance.
options.C: To select the best algorithm for the given task.
options.D: To interpret the learned model parameters.
